trans-unit.source: Description: Offer consumable in-app products&\#8212;items that can be purchased, used, and purchased again&\#8212;through the Store commerce platform to provide your customers with a purchase experience that is both robust and reliable.
trans-unit.target: Description: Offer consumable in-app products&\#8212;items that can be purchased, used, and purchased again&\#8212;through the Store commerce platform to provide your customers with a purchase experience that is both robust and reliable.

trans-unit.source: Enable consumable in-app product purchases
trans-unit.target: Enable consumable in-app product purchases

trans-unit.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132)

trans-unit.source: Offer consumable in-app products—items that can be purchased, used, and purchased again—through the Store commerce platform to provide your customers with a purchase experience that is both robust and reliable.
trans-unit.target: Offer consumable in-app products—items that can be purchased, used, and purchased again—through the Store commerce platform to provide your customers with a purchase experience that is both robust and reliable.

trans-unit.source: This is especially useful for things like in-game currency (gold, coins, etc.) that can be purchased and then used to purchase specific power-ups.
trans-unit.target: This is especially useful for things like in-game currency (gold, coins, etc.) that can be purchased and then used to purchase specific power-ups.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This topic covers the purchase and fulfillment reporting of consumable in-app products.
trans-unit.target: This topic covers the purchase and fulfillment reporting of consumable in-app products.

trans-unit.source: If you are unfamiliar with in-app products, please review [Enable in-app product purchases](enable-in-app-product-purchases.md) to learn about license information, and how to properly list in-app products in the Store.
trans-unit.target: If you are unfamiliar with in-app products, please review [Enable in-app product purchases](enable-in-app-product-purchases.md) to learn about license information, and how to properly list in-app products in the Store.

trans-unit.source: When you code and test new in-app products for the first time, you must use the [**CurrentAppSimulator**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779766) object instead of the [**CurrentApp**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779765) object.
trans-unit.target: When you code and test new in-app products for the first time, you must use the [**CurrentAppSimulator**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779766) object instead of the [**CurrentApp**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/hh779765) object.

trans-unit.source: This way you can verify your license logic using simulated calls to the license server instead of calling the live server.
trans-unit.target: This way you can verify your license logic using simulated calls to the license server instead of calling the live server.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you need to customize the file named "WindowsStoreProxy.xml" in %userprofile%\\AppData\\local\\packages\\<package name>\\LocalState\\Microsoft\\Windows Store\\ApiData.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you need to customize the file named "WindowsStoreProxy.xml" in %userprofile%\\AppData\\local\\packages\\<package name>\\LocalState\\Microsoft\\Windows Store\\ApiData.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Visual Studio simulator creates this file when you run your app for the first time—or you can also load a custom one at runtime.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Visual Studio simulator creates this file when you run your app for the first time—or you can also load a custom one at runtime.

trans-unit.source: For more info, see **CurrentAppSimulator**.
trans-unit.target: For more info, see **CurrentAppSimulator**.

trans-unit.source: This topic also references code examples provided in the [Store sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=627610).
trans-unit.target: This topic also references code examples provided in the [Store sample](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkID=627610).

trans-unit.source: This sample is a great way to get hands-on experience with the different monetization options provided for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: This sample is a great way to get hands-on experience with the different monetization options provided for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Making the purchase request
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Making the purchase request

trans-unit.source: The initial purchase request is made with [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263381) like any other purchase made through the Store.
trans-unit.target: The initial purchase request is made with [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263381) like any other purchase made through the Store.

trans-unit.source: The difference for consumable in-app products is that after a successful purchase, a customer cannot purchase the same product again until the app has notified the Store that the previous purchase was successfully fulfilled.
trans-unit.target: The difference for consumable in-app products is that after a successful purchase, a customer cannot purchase the same product again until the app has notified the Store that the previous purchase was successfully fulfilled.

trans-unit.source: It's your app's responsibility to fulfill purchased consumables and notify the Store of the fulfillment.
trans-unit.target: It's your app's responsibility to fulfill purchased consumables and notify the Store of the fulfillment.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows a consumable in-app product purchase request.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows a consumable in-app product purchase request.

trans-unit.source: You'll notice code comments indicating when your app should conduct its local fulfillment of the consumable in-app product for two different scenarios—when the request is successful, and when the request is not successful because of an unfulfilled purchase of that same product.
trans-unit.target: You'll notice code comments indicating when your app should conduct its local fulfillment of the consumable in-app product for two different scenarios—when the request is successful, and when the request is not successful because of an unfulfilled purchase of that same product.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Tracking local fulfillment of the consumable
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Tracking local fulfillment of the consumable

trans-unit.source: When granting your customer access to the consumable in-app product, it's important to keep track of which product is fulfilled (*productId*), and which transaction that fulfillment is associated with (*transactionId*).
trans-unit.target: When granting your customer access to the consumable in-app product, it's important to keep track of which product is fulfilled (*productId*), and which transaction that fulfillment is associated with (*transactionId*).

trans-unit.source: **Important** Your app is responsible for the accurately reporting fulfillment to the Store.
trans-unit.target: **Important** Your app is responsible for the accurately reporting fulfillment to the Store.

trans-unit.source: This step is essential to maintaining a fair and reliable purchase experience for your customers.
trans-unit.target: This step is essential to maintaining a fair and reliable purchase experience for your customers.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates use of the [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392) properties from the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263381) call in the previous step to identify the purchased product for fulfillment.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates use of the [**PurchaseResults**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263392) properties from the [**RequestProductPurchaseAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263381) call in the previous step to identify the purchased product for fulfillment.

trans-unit.source: An array is used to store the product information in a location that can later be referenced to confirm that local fulfillment was successful.
trans-unit.target: An array is used to store the product information in a location that can later be referenced to confirm that local fulfillment was successful.

trans-unit.source: This next example shows how to use the array from the previous example to access product ID/transaction ID pairs that are later used when reporting fulfillment to the Store.
trans-unit.target: This next example shows how to use the array from the previous example to access product ID/transaction ID pairs that are later used when reporting fulfillment to the Store.

trans-unit.source: **Important** Whatever methodology your app uses to track and confirm fulfillment, your app must demonstrate due diligence to ensure that your customers are not charged for items they haven't received.
trans-unit.target: **Important** Whatever methodology your app uses to track and confirm fulfillment, your app must demonstrate due diligence to ensure that your customers are not charged for items they haven't received.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Reporting product fulfillment to the Store
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Reporting product fulfillment to the Store

trans-unit.source: After local fulfillment is completed, your app must make a [**ReportConsumableFulfillmentAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263380) call that includes the *productId* and the transaction the product purchase is included in.
trans-unit.target: After local fulfillment is completed, your app must make a [**ReportConsumableFulfillmentAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263380) call that includes the *productId* and the transaction the product purchase is included in.

trans-unit.source: **Important** Failure to report fulfilled consumable in-app products to the Store will result in the user being unable to purchase that product again until fulfillment for the previous purchase is reported.
trans-unit.target: **Important** Failure to report fulfilled consumable in-app products to the Store will result in the user being unable to purchase that product again until fulfillment for the previous purchase is reported.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Identifying unfulfilled purchases
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Identifying unfulfilled purchases

trans-unit.source: Your app can use the [**GetUnfulfilledConsumablesAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263379) method to check for unfulfilled consumable in-app products at any time.
trans-unit.target: Your app can use the [**GetUnfulfilledConsumablesAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263379) method to check for unfulfilled consumable in-app products at any time.

trans-unit.source: This method should be called on a regular basis to check for unfulfilled consumables that exist due to unanticipated app events like an interruption in network connectivity or app termination.
trans-unit.target: This method should be called on a regular basis to check for unfulfilled consumables that exist due to unanticipated app events like an interruption in network connectivity or app termination.

trans-unit.source: The following example demonstrates how [**GetUnfulfilledConsumablesAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263379) can be used to enumerate unfulfilled consumables, and how your app can iterate through this list to complete local fulfillment.
trans-unit.target: The following example demonstrates how [**GetUnfulfilledConsumablesAsync**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/dn263379) can be used to enumerate unfulfilled consumables, and how your app can iterate through this list to complete local fulfillment.
